Ottawa, July 12th., 1939

Dear Sir:

The Department has received two or three applications for appointment as teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School, but we have advised these applicants that the present teacher, Miss Kelly, has not resigned her position.

Please make immediate inquiries and let me know if Miss Kelly desires to remain during the academic year 1939-40.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. Welfare & Training.

Robt. P. G. Lawrence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ontario.
Department of Justice Office,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In view of a vacancy of teacher on the Saguenay Reserve in the Catholic school would you consider me an applicant for the position. I am a qualified teacher with experience but I'm a married woman. My husband is a war veteran and is unable to secure employment. He suffers from the effects but draws only $15 monthly pension and we cannot make a go of it. Therefore, hearing there was to be a vacancy on the reserve I decided to apply for it.

I remember Mr. Hughes has kindly offered to recommend me. I also
refer you to Mr. George Andrews, Principal, Mississauga, Ont., and to Rev. Father E.E. Langan, our parish priest here, for references of my character, and to the Separate School Board, Mississauga, for references of my ability as a teacher.

In anticipation of an early and favourable reply,

Yours respectfully,

(Mrs.) Anna La Rue.
Dear Sir:

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant and also a communication received by you from Miss H. Kelly, teacher at the Sagamook Indian Day School, attached thereto.

I may state that the salaries paid by the Department to teachers in charge of Indian day schools have been very carefully reviewed by the Department during the last two months. There is a feeling here that the present salary schedule is rather high, with the result that members of Parliament are simply inundated with requests for positions at our schools. The salaries paid at present appear to be higher than the salaries paid at public schools for similar work. You may inform Miss Kelly, therefore, that the Department is not prepared to increase her salary at this time.

I am anxious to know if you have sent forward a requisition for the bed to which this teacher refers in her communication. If this request has not been sent forward to the Department, you might purchase a suitable bed for this school, from a firm on the approved list.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Laurence:

Mrs. Osborne, a widow, of Massey, is applying for the position of teacher in the Spanish River Reserve Catholic School, which I understand has been vacated by Miss Kelly.

Mrs. Osborne has asked me to write you in her behalf. I am very pleased to do so both for herself and in the best interests of the Indians. Mrs. Osborne is especially well gifted for service of this kind. She is highly trained in the domestic arts, dramatics, music - instrumental and vocal, her manners and living habits are exemplary. In short she is the ideal Indian school teacher, and I am confident you will have every reason to be grateful in having been able to secure her services, and I recommend her very highly.

Dear Sir:

I understand there is a vacancy for a teacher at the P.C. School for the Saguenay River Indian Reserve, and I hereby tender my application for the position.

I am a Roman Catholic, and have had 14 years experience teaching. I urge not teaching during the period when school certificates were made by necessity but continued my Summer Course and thus the subjects taught to a second.

I have considerable experience in dramatics, household science, professional music, piano, violin, church and cultural training and am also educated in French.

My elder sister was for many years a Sister who devoted her life to the
Indians in the Indian Industrial School at Spanish have frequently played there for their concerts and also assisted the girls and boys' schools when they presented an opera.

Trusting my application will receive your favorable consideration, I am

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

It has been brought to the attention of the Department recently that the attendance at the Sagamook School during the month of September is probably as good as during any other month in the year.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Bethune's memorandum of July 30 in which he states that Mrs. Osborne has been recommended for the position of teacher at the Sagamook School. It is also noted that Mrs. Osborne holds a Province of Ontario third-class certificate.

In the case of a school where English is the language of instruction the only third-class certificate that is recognized is one that was obtained several years ago and was later validated by regulation of the Department of Education at Toronto. I understand that there are few of these and a teacher holding one of them would have great difficulty in obtaining a position in either a public or separate school in the Province of Ontario.

For many years past only first-class and second-class certificates have been awarded and at the present time those attending normal schools are required to have a first-class certificate.

It is certain that in view of recent changes in the curriculum for the Province of Ontario a teacher holding a third-class certificate of the type mentioned above would not be as capable of instructing the pupils as a teacher who has passed through normal school within recent years and holds a second-class certificate or, preferably, a first-class certificate.
The former teacher of the Sagamook School, Miss Kelly, held a first-class certificate and according to the Inspector's reports did very good work. Under these circumstances I believe that it would not be in the best interests of the Indian pupils attending this school to appoint any other teacher than one possessing a first-class certificate and I feel that it should be possible to secure such a teacher.

Before taking any action regarding the appointment of Mrs. Osborne I thought it advisable to bring the above to your attention. I should appreciate receiving further instructions regarding the teaching services at this school for the coming academic year.

[Signature]

Director.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Sagamook Indian Day School on the 30th ultimo Inspector Greening suggests that the school should be kept open in September and closed in June.

When it was decided to reduce the academic year to 8 months at Indian day schools it was believed that the best results would be obtained by operating from October 1 to the following June 30. In a few instances there have been exceptions to this decision in the past but this year we are making a decided effort to have all schools operate during the months mentioned above. Any deviation from this rule causes considerable administration difficulties, especially in connection with payment of salaries.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Madam:

There is a vacancy at the Sagamook Indian Day School which is located on the Spanish River Reserve, about five miles from Massey, Ont. There is a combined school and teacher's residence. The latter is furnished with everything except blankets and linen which are supplied by the teacher and are removed when she gives up duties.

Dear Madam:

Memorandum

Classroom Inspection Report - Shingok Indian Day School.

This school was inspected on February 5th. The teacher is Miss E. Burke, First Class Certificate, twenty-nine years' Indian experience and five years' Provincial experience. This building is quite satisfactory; it was built in 1935. There is a full basement with a satisfactory furnace. There are five windows on one side of the room and one on the other. It is lined with V Joint on the lower part of the wall and beaver board on the upper.

The basement is also well lighted and could quite easily be used for manual training and Domestic Science. These children are bright and eager. Their attendance is very good and there are some thirty-eight children enrolled. Miss Burke is a strict disciplinarian and drives the children a lot but they like her and are eager to show what they can do. The condition of the class is good. In Arithmetic the children are fairly good and are exceptionally good in spelling. They read and speak out well. There is an organ in the classroom and the children are very fond of singing.

The teacher's quarters are at the back of the school and are small. However, an extra room has been added and when this is completed, can be used for an extra bedroom. There is a housekeeper with Miss Burke.

RECOMMENDATIONS:

1. That an extra classroom be opened in this area.
2. That the Indian Agent approach the Council with a view of renting the Council Hall for such a use.
3. That we obtain an estimate of the cost of renovating the Council Hall for use as an extra classroom for 1948-49.
4. That a new classroom be built in 1949-50.

Bernard F. Henry,
Dept. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Neary:

May I draw your attention again to the need of a second teacher in our school.

In a recent survey I have found out that about sixteen pupils will enter school for the first time in September. This will increase the registration to sixty. I need not go into detail re the difficulty of handling such a large number. Two problems, however, stand out prominently:

1st. The larger boys, for want of attention and variety in their work, grow disgusted and wish to give school up entirely;

2nd. The little ones, not getting sufficient attention, form habits of idleness etc. which remain with them and, as progress is naturally slow where English is not understood, these juniors who should pass into second year at least at the end of two years, remain primers, or at best, firsts. They in turn will be beyond their grade age in a few years and become restless and disinterested in the work.

On May 12th I discussed this question with Agent Laurence and Inspector Greening. They both agreed that a second teacher was essential if any real progress was to be made.

If the work on our living apartments can be completed as I outlined for Mr. Laurence, we will have an extra room which can be used as a bedroom in case of necessity. This would permit a third person to live in the teachorage.

There is question of opening a class in the basement. This, I think, would be as good an arrangement as any we can
Mr. Bernard Neary, Supt.

The question of having water in the house seems to present difficulty. I might tell you that since December our pump has been out of order and we have been carrying water from a spring quite a distance from the school. Permission was given to buy a new pump and also for repairs on the old one, but men were scarce from the reserve trapping and we had not one who understood the work; consequently the new pump reclined peacefully in the basement till about a week ago. The men are installing it today.

Regarding the second classroom, no doubt you will hear from Mr. Laurence and Mr. Greening. I know this matter will meet with your kind co-operation and help.

Dear Miss Burke:

I have received your letter of the 5th ultimo in connection with the installation of a telephone line on the reserve.

As you know, the installation of a telephone line is not exactly the duty of the Indian Education Division, and consequently, I discussed the contents of your letter with the officials who are in charge of the general administration of reserves. They have made extensive enquiries and have ascertained that it would cost at least $2,000.00 to provide a telephone line, and as we would not count on any customers who would pay their share of the maintenance cost, the Departmental officials cannot see that they would be justified in incurring the expenditure. It is a further fact that no funds have been provided in the current year's appropriation nor in next year's appropriation for the provision of a telephone line on the reserve. Dear Gertrude:

I was surprised to receive your letter of the 9th May, and to find you saying that "As yet I have not yet secured a position," because I am pretty well certain that the Indian Affairs Branch has one reserved for you.

There are many more people that you might think who are watching your progress with much interest and high hopes. Among them are Colonel Henry, the Superintendent of Indian Education, and myself. We are all anxious to see Indian young people given as good an start as they are prepared to make for themselves, and every success not only makes us feel proud but also makes another such success so much the more likely.

And so it is for that reason that the Indian School people at Ottawa thought it might be a good plan if, where possible, promising young teachers be sent to a two-room (or larger) school where they could be under the care and guidance of an older experienced teacher, and thus serve a term of "apprenticeship," although they are FULL RANK teachers and paid and treated as such.

Besides a number of letters, Colonel Henry and I have had two conversations about what would be best for you, one in Ottawa in February, and one in Toronto at Easter, so that you can see we have been thinking a good deal about you, which is why I was surprised to hear that you were still worrying about a position.

Colonel Henry asked me for my advice, and I suggested that you go offered the school at Sagamook, just south of Massay. I don't know just how far it is, but I have heard of the school from Massay and back again so that it can sit by very far. You will have the junior room, with not more than nine or ten One and Two pupils (possibly more from the town), and very likely since we want to give you every chance to get along. The Principal is Miss Sadie Burke, whom you may remember as she was once Principal at Wikwemikong, when that school was giving work as high as Grades Nine and Ten, and when I was passing pupils from the school on recommendation while I was making many pupils from Provincial Schools write the examinations.

Miss Burke has had years and years of experience in Indian schools, and should be able to help you a great deal. Besides when you will be able to live in the school residence.

Here are a good many reasons why you would be better off NOT to accept a position in a Residential School. If I could have a talk with you I could tell you more, but it would make this letter too long. One thing is that if you go to parish, you won't be in my inspectorate, so that I won't be able to help you along, although, of course, some other inspector would do as well.
I certainly hope that you take this position at Sagamook, because I gave a good deal of thought to finding you a good school, and would have chosen the same school for you, for the first year, even if you had been my own daughter.

If you would like to take the school, you should write at once to:

Lieut.-Col. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Tell him that I have written to you about a school with the Indian Affairs Branch, and add that you would take the Sagamook school if it were vacant.

You needn't write a long letter, because Colonel Neary knows all about you.

Yours very sincerely,

Miss Gertrude Pitawanakwat,
St. Mary's Academy,
Karth Bay, Ontario.

Miss Margaret MacNulty, 31 Hall Avenue East, Renfrew, Ontario, has been engaged as a school teacher in the Indian Affairs Branch and last Fall was posted on Cornwall Island. She took ill there and had to leave to undergo treatment, for which the Indian Agent allowed her one week's leave. She eventually was replaced and was given one week's salary instead of the usual month's salary which, I understand, all teachers receive in such instances.

At Christmas 1948, Mr. Neary, the Superintendent of Indian Education offered Miss MacNulty one of two isolated schools in the Port Arthur area, which she had to decline on account of illness in the family.

In the meantime, she received a letter from Mr. Fee with two months' retirement fund and indicating that due to a break in her service he was obliged to return this money.

Miss MacNulty states that any break in her service were always due to illness. She still has the cheque uncashed, as she wishes to leave the fund intact until she can again resume teaching. However, she has so far not been offered any appointment for the coming year and I wish to enquire whether there is anything in the way of a position in store for her.

Honourable C. W. G. Gibson,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA - Canada.
Would you be good enough to have the matter investigated and inform me of its present status.

Sincerely yours,

(sgd) James J. McCann,
Minister.

Ottawa, October 27, 1922.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your recent letter regarding the amount paid you as teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School for the quarter ending September 30th, last.

In reply I beg to say that you were engaged at a salary of $600.00 per annum. In the case of new teachers, the Department pays for the September quarter the proportion which the number of days taught during that quarter bears to the total number of teaching days in the school year. There are 200 teaching days and, as the return showed that the school was open for 17 days, you were paid 17/200 of your yearly salary of $600.00, or $51.00.

If you continue in charge of this school you will be paid at the end of the December quarter, one-quarter of your yearly salary and the same amount at the end of the March quarter. When your June quarter return is received all previous returns will be checked and, if it is found that you have taught the full 200 days, you will then be paid the balance of your yearly salary.

The bonus due you for the month of September will be paid with the December quarter bonus.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

Sir,

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, informing the Department that owing to ill health, Miss T. McPaul, teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School, has requested leave of absence.

Sir:

Ottawa, September 2, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, informing the Department of the resignation of Miss Helena T. Connolly as teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School and recommending, owing to the irregular attendance, that this school be closed until such time as a new building on a more central site can be erected. In checking up the enrolment and average attendance during the past few years, the Department agrees with you that it would not be possible to close this school until a new school building can be provided. We do not hope to be able to do next summer. You will therefore inform the Indian parents that the school will not be in operation during the coming academic year. It is noted that you have discussed the matter of closing this school with the Separate School Inspector.

You were informed, on the 25th ultimo, of the appointment of Miss Theresa McNeil as teacher of this school. In this connection I may say that Miss McNeil now states she will be unable to accept the position.

You should see that the doors and windows of the present school building are securely fastened and that all school material is properly stored.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

With reference to the Sagamook Indian Day School, which is now under construction, it has been decided to appoint Miss Honorine Kelly, of Spanish, Ont., as teacher.

Miss Kelly holds a First Class Certificate and also a Grade "B" Certificate for Physical Training. Salary will be allowed her at the rate of $50 a teaching month from the date on which she begins duties.

As soon as the school is ready, you should advise Miss Kelly the exact date on which you desire her to open the school.

I am enclosing a Staff Questionnaire which you should have Miss Kelly complete and return to the Department. I am also enclosing a circular regarding the dates of opening and closing of Indian day schools, which you should hand to Miss Kelly.

The Deputy Superintendent General:-

Mr Agent Hagan, who was written to for a report on repairs needed for the Sagamook school, writes stating that the Band at their last Council meeting were unanimous in voting for a new school building, which would provide suitable quarters for the teacher. Specifications for the erection of an Indian Schoolhouse at Sagamook.

Description:

A two story frame building on a stone foundation. Size 30 ft. by 22 ft. with a porch 5 ft. by 10 ft. Height of the ceilings above the ground and first floors to be 9 ft. and 8 ft. 6 ins. respectively.

Plain rubble masonry. The walls are to be 16 ins. thick; 3 ft. 6 ins. in the ground and 1 ft. 6 ins. above. The outside walls are to be pointed above the ground. Build two piers, 20 ins. square of brick or stone to receive the 8 ins. by 8 ins. columns as per drawing.

The walls, piers and chimney are to have footing courses extending 6 ins. on either side and 6 ins. thick.

Lay 2 ins. planking on the top of the walls and piers and bed the same in mortar ready to receive the joists.

Build from the foundation course already mentioned, a one-half brick chimney with three flues, 8 ins. by 8 ins.

Form an open fire-place with brick hearth 16 ins. wide in the school-room as shown on the drawing. The portion of the chimney in the first floor is to be plastered on the outside the same as the walls; the chimney in the school-room is to be built of selected bricks and left bare. Carry the chimney to a height of at least one foot above the ridge roll of the roof and carefully purge the flues throughout their length.

Provide and fit suitable scot boxes and doors; and make pipe holes and supply the thimbles, etc. required where shown in the chimney and over the doors.
doors and in the floor as per drawing.

Ventilators.

Put four iron ventilators in the outer walls of the school-room, two on either side of the room.

Lay a suitable cold air duct from the outside to the stove, also provide a galvanized iron jacket to enclose the stove around the back and sides extending to the floor, properly framed and secured to the floor.

Beams and columns

The ground and first floors are to be supported where shown by 8 in. by 12 in. pine beams, expanding in one piece from end to end of the building.

The beam over the school-room is to be supported where shown on the drawing by 8 in. by 12 in. pine columns resting directly on the 8 in. by 12 in. beam below.

Chamfer the angles of the 8 in. by 8 in. posts.

Joists.

The floor joists of the ground and first floors are to be 2 ins. by 12 ins. and 2 ins. by 10 ins., respectively set at 2 ft. centres and to be continuous from wall to wall, i.e., 22 ft. long.

Double joists under the partitions and 4 ins thick joists for trimmers for the stairs.

Lay one row of herring-bone bridging down the centre of the longer span of the ground and first floor joists.

Ceiling joists to be 2 in. by 8 ins. set at 16 in. centres and well nailed to the rafters.

For the second story; to be 1½ dressed, tongued and grooved, blind nailed; for the ground floor to be the same laid on a floor of one inch rough boarding. This one inch rough boarding is to be put on diagonally and well nailed to the joists.

Flooring

Studding.

The studs of the walls and the partitions are to be 2 ins. by 4 ins. at 16 inch centres. Double at all windows, doors, corners, etc.

Outside
Walls

Outside walls to be boarded on the outside with 1 in. rough boarding and covered with tar paper and clapboarded.

The inside of the walls and partitions and ceilings, except the underside of the wainscoting of the schoolroom, porch and kitchen, which is to be receive but one coat of plaster, are to be lathed and plastered in two coat work and hard finished.

Wall plates 2 ins. by 4 ins. double.

Wainscoting

Wainscot the walls of the schoolroom, porch and kitchen with double beaded sheeting, 4 ft. high surmounted with a cap. The wainscoting is to be well nailed to the studs and lathing.

Roof

The rafters are to be 2 ins. by 8 ins. at 16 ins. centres. Cover the rafters with rough boarding tar paper and shingle with best sawn cedar shingles, 5 ins. to the weather. The hips and ridge of the roof to be covered with weather boards and roll.

The eaves and cornices are to be plainly finished with 1 in. dressed boards.

Doors

The porch and schoolroom doors are to be 4 ft. by 7 ft., four panelled and 1½ ins. thick. Both doors are to be provided with strong serviceable locks with two keys each.

Doors of the first floor to be 2 ft. 8 ins. by 6 ft. 8 ins., four panelled and 1½ ins. thick and provided with suitable locks, handles, etc.

Windows

To be in two sashes. The upper sash fixed; the lower to raise. The two windows in the rear to be similar to the two front ones. Glaze with two lights over the entrance door of the porch.

Provide and fit all necessary fixtures.

Architraves
Architraves

Carry simple architraves at least 5 inches wide around the windows and doors and a 10 in. wide base board at the base of all walls.

Hooks and shelves.

Provide and place three dozen wire hooks in the living and bed-room closets and in the hall. Put a shelf 6 ft. above the floor in the closets of these rooms. The kitchen closet if to be fitted up with shelves for a pantry.

Platform.

Build a raised platform 2x4 ft. 8 ins. wide and 9 ins. above the level of the school-room where shown on the drawing.

The spaces on the rear wall between the chimney and each side wall are to be painted on the plaster with prepared blackboard paint, to a height of 3 ft. 6 ins. above the top of the wainscoting.

Form a ledge on the top of the wainscoting to hold the brushes and chalk.

Stairs.

Build stairs to the first floor where shown on the drawing in a neat substantial manner; width of stairs 2 ft., 9 ins. Fifteen risers, 10 ins. treads.

The stairs will be enclosed below in matched and beaded sheeting with a closet under. Simple handrail balusters and newel post in the hall above.

Porch.

The foundation, flooring and walls are to be the same as the main building. Joists 2 ins. by 6 ins. at 16 inch centres. Rafters 2 ins. by 4 ins. at 16 inch centres braced half-way up with 1 in. by 3 in. braces; these with the end of the rafters will form the ceiling. Ceiling to be lathed and plastered two coat work; hand finish.

Build strong and properly footed steps to the porch.

Painting
Painting

Prime and paint in two coat work with white lead and linseed oil paint or approved colors, the whole of the wood work both outside and inside, usually painted.

General

A good plain substantial building complete in every respect is to be erected of sound materials and good workmanship. It is to be subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent or other officer who may be appointed by the Department of Indian Affairs for the purpose.

The Deputy Supt. General,

Three tenders have been received for the erection of the school-house on the Thessalon Indian reserve, Ont., amounting respectively to $1,364., $1,525., and $1,600. These tenders were received closed. The Agent appears to have acted in accordance with instructions contained in a letter to him of the 12th instant.

We usually ask the Agent to open the tenders, and to recommend which tender should be accepted, at the same time reporting his reasons for making the said recommendation. I have no knowledge the three persons making the tenders above referred to. We have, therefore, to ask a further report from the Indian Agent.

The lowest tender, that of James Sandie for $1364., is rather high for a good locality, but considering that Thessalon is more or less inaccessible, I think his tender may be accepted, provided the Agent reports that he is a fit and proper person.

It is desirable that the school-house should be built before the winter commences. In order that no time may be lost, I beg to recommend that an Order in Council be immediately applied for authorizing the expenditure of $1,400. in the erection of the said school-house.

General Conditions.

The contractors are to give their personal supervision to the work, to furnish all necessary material, labour, apparatus, scaffolding and utensils needed for performing the work in the best and most satisfactory manner according to the drawings and specifications prepared for the work and intended to include everything necessary and conducive for the full and entire completion of the building, notwithstanding, every item necessarily involved is not particularly mentioned, and nor is any particular and very varied and extensive.

All the internal and external qualities specified and

At the completion thereof, the structure shall be in a complete and unimpaired state.

...concrete to the depth of ... inches on foundation trench and footings, walls and floors.

The excavation to be ...

Then wall above to allow for ... suitable bottom, in not great depth, excavation to be continued to ...

Leveling...

When the stone work is completed the earth...
will be properly levelled to a grade from walls.

Stone Walls:
The foundation walls and piers to be of plain rubble masonry, 10" thick with footing 6" thick and extending at least 6" wider on each side than walls above. The edges to be laid on the natural bed in good mortar, closely packed and heaped and well flushed up on each course.

Bond Stones:
Put bond stones reaching through wall at least 3 to every yard of face work, and well flush up both sides of stone walls before grading and filling in behind walls and piers.

Jointing:
The portion of stone wall shown above ground to be neatly pointed up showing natural core of stones.

Chimneys:
Built from bracket as shown in rear end of schoolroom, brick chimney having two flues 9 X 9 each. The chimney to be built of good hard burned brick in good mortar and well flushed up each course. The flues to be raised their full height.

Lap for Foundations:
Properly level and bed in good mortar 2" X 6" plates in long length on stone wall and piers to carry jointing.

Provide and fix where shown on piers, lap 6" X 8" formed of 3 pieces of 2 X 8 well braced nailed together to carry jointing.

Joists:
The jointing for ground floor will be of 4" X 10" first floor of 3 X 10 all to be set at 16" centres and well nailed to plates. The trimmers and rail for stair to be doubled.
Bridging:-
Bridge ground floor joists on each side between beam and walls and first floor joists to have three rows of herring-bone bridging well nailed with 3" nails at each end to joist.

Ceiling Joists:-
The ceiling joists will be of 2 X 6 set at 16" centres and well spiked as collar ties to rafters.

Studding:-
Frame all outside walls of 2" X 4" studding, doubled at corners and at all openings and set at 16" centres well nailed to plates at foot and to sides of joisting with 4" spike nails. First floor joisting to be supported on ribband piece of 1" X 4" cut into studding and well spike nailed to stud with 4" nails at each end. The plates carrying rafters to be of 2 X 4 doubled in long lengths and strongly spike together.

All interior partitions to be of 2 X 4 set at 16" centres and to have head and foot plates.

Cover all outside walls and roof (laid close joints) with good quality sound common boarding well nailed with, at least, two nails at each crossing or stud with 8" nails.

Building Paper:-
Cover all outside walls and roof with two thicknesses of (broken joints) of tarred roofing paper of good quality to be strongly tacked and secured to boarding before siding is put on.

Siding:-
All external angles to be covered with thickness of tarred felt protecting angles. All angles to have strips 1" X 4" to which the siding will be butted as well as back band to all frames (see margin) making a neat and satisfactory finish.
The siding to be of pine narrow and of good quality to be well nailed at each corner of studding with 8d finishing nails.

Rafters:
The rafters to be 2 X 6" at 10" centres, to be framed at heel and securely spike nailed to plates.

Shingles:
Cover the roof with best quality of cedar shingles laid at 5° to weather and nailed with best quality of steel shingle nails. (at least 2 nails to each 4" shingle.)

Window Frames:
All window frames to be 7/8" box frames having all necessary hanging stiles, blind stiles, posting strips, sills, sub-sills, etc., also back band to which siding will be finished. The sash will be 1½" double hung and to have lites and fasts complete. The sills to be of 3 X 4" order.

Door Frames:
The frames for outside doors will be of 1½" pine rebated for 1½" doors and to have similar casing and back band to window frames.

The exterior doors to be 1½" thick, to have bolection moulds and interior door 1½" thick flush nailed, all to be of first quality pine. All outside doors to be hinged with 4 X 4, and outside doors with 3½ X 5½ loose pin steel butt.

The exterior doors to have strong lock with 2 keys and further secured by strong bolts to anch. All other doors to be 2ft 6" X 6ft. 6" and to have suitable brass-faced and bolted morticed door locks complete.

Flooring:
The ground floor joist will be covered, close jointed, with a good quality of (dressed one side)
7/8" common bo-siling laid diagonally and well nailed at each crossing of joisting with 2½" nails.

The sub-floor to be covered with one thickness of tarred roofing felt. When this is finished cover ground and first floor joints with good quality of 1½" narrow tongued and grooved pine flooring blind nailed at each crossing of joints with 3" wire nails.

Ceilings:

The schoolroom ceiling will be covered with good quality of narrow pine jointed shooting well and carefully blind nailed to joists.

Joining:

The schoolroom entrance, clock room, stairway, etc., will be sheathed up to a height of 6' 6" to have a neat cap finish in pine, all to be well and strongly blind nailed to studging and ribboned.

Walls:

It is to all rooms, closets, etc., shot with 1" length of batten board 7/8" x 10" pine and 5" moulding to all doors and window frames, and shelf in closets, pantries, etc., and most about the doors and shelves to cupboard as shown.

I am surprised at Mr. Jas. Sandie was given the contract to build the Saganock school, after the bad work he has done here on our school. He left the Church unfinished, sheathed it inside with very bad lumber full of cracks, loose nails and holes; he put matched boarding on end or perpendicularly for the inside walls, before putting the floor, and thus left a hole in the floor along the wall at every point of the matched-boards. He left out a great part of the quarter-round, put no half-round nosing in front of the step of the sanctuary, made a hole in the wall between the sanctuary and the vestry over the altar for a stove-pipe, and when told that it was not on the plan, he did not fill the hole properly, but simply nailed two unsightly boards over the hole left out two crosses on the Church, which the plan called for, put nothing in the belfry to prevent the rain water from running through the roof. When Mr. Clinton came to paint the Church he remarked that it was half finished; he hesitated to paint the roof, saying that the loose shingles moved under the brush, many being held in place only by one nail. Mr. Clinton had to put sine in places to cover under the shingles to cover open joints.

Regards,

With best wishes,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very respectfully,

Sir,

I beg leave to say that I have made a thorough examination of the Seguin Indian school house and I would advise the following improvements. I would advise storm sash put on each window. The price would be as follows: four windows upstairs $2.50 each glazed complete; four large windows downstairs $3.00 each glazed complete; one window downstairs $1.60 glazed complete; two small windows downstairs glazed complete $0.50 each.

At that rate the whole 11 windows would cost $25.40. To mend the plaster would cost for lime and labor would cost about $10.00. We would also want 24 lengths of stove pipe and one elbow.

The closets would cost about $5.00 in material and labor. The fence around the school would be best as we only want a small enclosure enough to have flower beds around the school. 60 feet on each end and 87 feet on each side which would be about 18 rods in circumference at about $0.50 per rod.

Two small pigs gates $4.00 each about 16 feet, figuring up all the school house, the barn, and the fencing it would cost about at least $60.00. I would not advise buying a stove at the present time as we cannot get a stove with an oven unless we get a cooking stove and that would not be suitable for cooking and heating the class room.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing the sanitary inspection report of Dr. McDermott on the Sagamook Indian Day School, in which he states that the plaster in the schoolroom is broken in several places and that the walls should be painted at once. He further states that several seats in the schoolroom require repairs, and that the doors and windows of the closets should be repaired at once.

May 24, 1923.

Classroom could be heated reasonably well but the teacher claims that the wind whistles in everywhere round the windows, etc., in her apartments. Wainscoting allow wind to come through.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Sagamook Indian Day School, May 14, 1925.

(A) Rooms should be decorated or morewood.

(B) Teacher has painted the floor in kitchen.

(C) Outbuildings need cleaning badly. These toilets are being used by some Indian people living there and they have made them most dirty. The teacher cannot do anything. The trouble is also due to the fact that there is a wire fence around the school itself but the woodshed and toilets are outside this fence on open land. The wood too has been disappearing. I would suggest that the fence be extended to enclose all. Also that immediate cleaning of toilets be attended to and that locks be placed on these doors.

The stove here is of an old type and will burn every baking put in. This teacher can only get in supplies about three times every term. You can see then how important a good stove is to a teacher. There seems a tendency to put in any old type on the part of some agents.

Three pipes needed to be replaced in teacher's bedroom. They smoke. Broom needed. Axe handle needed.

J. M. Bennett,

Ottawa, May 22, 1925.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Sagamook Indian Day School, has made the following recommendations:

1. Rooms in teacher's residence should be decorated or murescod.
2. Outbuildings need cleaning badly.
3. A new stove is required by the teacher for cooking purposes.
4. Three pipes needed in teacher's bedroom.
5. Broom required.
6. Axe handle required.

With reference to the cleaning of the teacher's rooms, please state whether you would recommend that this work be done. If so, you should report the amount of work required and the approximate cost.

Regarding the outbuildings, the inspector states that these toilets are being used by the Indian people and that the trouble is due to the fact that there is a wire fence around the school itself but the woodshed and toilet are outside this fence. The wood has been disappearing. The fence should be extended to enclose the toilets and woodshed and locks should be placed on the doors. Please arrange to have these toilets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good sanitary condition. You should purchase locks and have them installed on the doors. The keys should be in the teacher's possession. Please state what it would cost to have the fence extended around these two outbuildings.

Regarding the stove for the teacher's use, please state whether you would recommend that a new one be supplied. If so, you should consult the teacher as to the type of stove needed and inform the Department as to its approximate cost. You may purchase any extra stove pipe required, also one broom and one axe handle.

You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure which you are authorized to make. Also forward a report as soon as possible, regarding the other recommendations of the inspector.

Dear Sir,

Re the school of Sagamook—While at Sagamook Miss Laura Sloan, teacher, came to pay me a visit and in tears she told me how hard it was to stay there. And the cause of the difficulties is the chief. The teacher is enslaved by him, everywhere even in her class. She should be absolutely independent of him, a poor Indian who cannot sign his name. Till now the teacher depends on him, or to fix the school or to split the wood necessary for cooking, etc. He is paid for that, but as it bothers him to be asked, not doing as he should do, he gets angry and gets rid of the teacher quick and so the poor girl is obliged to split her wood as she had to do for two months last fall and frequently at other times.

If he is told something by his adopted girl, she being scolded for her misbehaviour, he goes himself or he sends his simpleton son John, to scold the teacher. That John told the girl not to accept any punishment from the teacher, because she is not the chief. At last she got the girl out the school, after much trouble.

The chief is supposed to put the storm windows, though asked repeatedly he neglected to put one, that was the cause of the teacher freezing all the winter, and also one pane of 30x18.
Ottawa, May 3, 1927.

Sir:

The Department is informed that the teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School has been having difficulty with Chief Louis Solomon, regarding the splitting of the wood necessary for cooking and in connection with other work to which he should attend. It is stated that the teacher has been obliged to split her own wood, which she did for two months last fall and frequently at other times. We are informed that the Chief neglected to put on one of the storm windows, although asked repeatedly by the teacher to do so, also that one pane of glass is required. It is stated, further, that the Chief and his son, John, have interfered with the work in the classroom.

The account which you submitted, for work done at the school by John Solomon in putting 30 cords of wood into the woodshed and taking down the storm windows, will not be paid until the Department hears from you as to whether Solomon is faithfully performing these services.

I may say the Department expects that an agent will see that the Indians or others do not interfere with the teacher's activities in the classroom and that, when the work of supplying and splitting wood is given, it will be properly done. It has been suggested that, in future, Constable Rossaw perform the work that has been carried out by Chief Solomon and that, if this arrangement were made, there would be no cause for complaint.

I have to request that you will enquire personally into the above matters and furnish the Department with a full report, stating whether Chief Solomon attends promptly to any duties which the teacher requires in the taking off and putting on double windows and the supplying of necessary wood.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

I have been transferred from Wikwemikong to Spanish, to take charge of the Indian Missions on this end, namely Sagamok, Spanish River, Oak Bay, Renabutch, Spragg, Mississaging and Les Sable.

I have been here since the 1st of October and have been around all the missions twice already.

I just returned last night from Sagamok. I spent five days there, visiting them all, including those along the Spanish River, and really Mr. Phelan, they are in a deplorable state for want of a school, so I am appealing to the Department of Indian affairs to have something done in their behalf.

I understand there was some trouble there a couple of years ago about the location of the school but that can be overcome now, by having a school about three miles and a half from the River on the Sagamok road. Some of the Indians are moving down toward the River from the Sagamok end, and others have told me that they would move there too, if a school was built there. They are just beginning to start to farm now, so it looks as if they are going to settle down.

There are about fifteen Catholic families within five miles of the River, with about forty children in all. There would be about twenty ready for school next September. They are nearly all young married Indians there and their families are increasing rapidly. In a few years time there will be thirty or forty children for that school.

There is a Protestant Anglican school on the River bank, across from Mr. Cole's farm. Of course as you know the Catholics are not allowed to send their children there without a dispensation from the Catholic Bishop, which he will not grant.

As soon as the Indians in that locality heard that I was appointed to Sagamok, some of them began sending their children to the Protestant school. Of course I had to forbid them under pain of refusing them the Sacraments and Catholic Burial. Some of them said that the Indian Agent told them to send their children there. I don't know if this is true or not, but I would like you to tell the Agent that the Catholic children are not allowed to go to that Protestant school.

Along the road from the River to what used to be Sagamok village there is a mountain of rock, about a mile and a half wide. There are quite a few Indian families scattered thru the Reserve beyond this mountain. They are anxious to have a school over there too, and they are willing to have the school now about three miles and a half from the River, with the hope that as time goes on, their numbers will increase, so that they could get a little school somewhere in that part of the Reserve. Dear Father Dwyer,

MEMORANDUM

Accompanied by Mr. Agent Rothera, I visited the new Sagamook Indian Day School, on the Spanish River Reserve, on January 21st.

The building had been completed at the end of December, and classes were opened on January 7th.

Miss Kelly, who was appointed teacher, holds a First Class Certificate and has had Normal School training. She appeared to be very much interested in her work. Twenty-six (26) children were present on the date of my visit, and the school register showed that this number had attended since the opening. It is expected that about fourteen (14) more children will attend as soon as weather conditions improve.

This school is well situated, and the majority of the children live a comparatively short distance from the school.

The building was erected by day labour, under a foreman, according to plans supplied the Agent by our Architect. It is one of the finest day schools that I have ever seen, and I feel that the Indian Agent deserves credit for the manner in which he has supervised the work. The building is 50' x 22', with a fine classroom; also living room, kitchen and bedroom for the teacher. There is a cement basement under the school. The posts in the basement are also made of cement. This basement is about 7' high and has ample room for storing wood.

Approximately two acres around the school was cleared, stumped and levelled. As a result, there will be plenty of room for playgrounds and, in addition, it reduces the fire hazard, as there is no bush near the school.

The only desks in the school are 9 double desks, seating 18 children, which were used in the old school. Twenty-two new single desks are required, and I would recommend that these be ordered as soon as possible.

Owing to the supervision of the Agent, the furniture for the teacher's residence used in the old building had been carefully stored and has been removed to the new school. As a result, no further equipment in this regard is required at the present time.

Water is obtained from a spring near the school, and two new toilets were erected.

The total cost of this school is as follows:

| Building material | £2,683.89 |
|-------------------|-----------|
| Labour            | £2,158.55 |
| **Total**         | £4,842.44 |

The above figure includes the installation of a furnace, which heats the whole building, also the cost of clearing the two acres of land.

Taking everything into consideration, I feel that we have received splendid value for the money expended.

Dear Sir:

In accordance with your letter 35-6-6, December 1940, on my last visit to the Sagamook Indian Day School Spanish River Reserve, I investigated conditions regarding a hot lunch at this School and found that majority of the pupils had to walk a distance of two and three miles to school over difficult trails, and although a number of them bring a lunch, some are unable to bring very much. During the cold weather they need something hot at noon. If the teacher does not supply a lunch, it means that they have nothing to eat. The teacher also finds that giving a hot lunch improves the attendance of those who live at a distance.

Miss Muldoon has written me stating that the $2.00 she was allowed is now used up, and as hot lunches are necessary for about six weeks more, she will require about $4.00 to finish the term.

Kindly advise if she can be allowed this amount.

Yours very truly,

R.P.G. Laurence

Yours very truly,

Mr. Philip Phelan

Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The sleeping quarters at Sagamook School is small, even for one person. Two of our teachers, as you know, have to be accommodated in this small room—not big enough to divide.

There is, however, a good shed attached to the building. If this could be finished for a kitchen with cement foundation, one of the rooms downstairs could be used as a bedroom. I really cannot understand how two of our teachers slept, or pretended to, in that small space. Will you please consider this request favorably, having this work commenced as soon as possible.

Another request. Would the Department give us a sewing machine with all the equipment that goes along with the "Singer" machine? I should be glad to commence sewing lessons as early as possible in the term.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Mr. R.F.C. Laurence, Indian Agent, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,

We have a communication from Miss Sadie Burke who is now teacher of the Sagamook Day School for the coming academic year.

She states that the living accommodation is too small and makes the following suggestion:

"There is a good shed attached to the building. If this could be finished off for a kitchen with cement foundation one of the rooms downstairs could be used as a bedroom."

It appears that this is a reasonable request and it would be appreciated if you could arrange to have the necessary work done as soon as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sadie Burke.

Mr. R.P.C. Lawrence,

We have received a letter from Miss Burke regarding the need for a second teacher at this school. Her letter, in part, reads as follows:

"May I draw your attention again to the need of a second teacher in our school.

"In a recent survey I have found out that about sixteen pupils will enter school for the first time in September. This will increase the registration to sixty. I need not go into detail re the difficulty of handling such a large number. Two problems, however, stand out prominently:

"1st, The larger boys, for want of attention and variety in their work, grow disgusted and wish to give school up entirely;

"2nd, The little ones, not getting sufficient attention, form habits of idleness, etc., which remain with them and, consequently, are naturally slow where English is not understood; these juniors who should pass into second year at least at the end of two years, remain primers, or at best, firsts. They in turn will be beyond their grade age in a few years and become restless and disinterested in the work."
"On May 12th I discussed this question with Agent Lawrence and Inspector Creasing. They both agreed that a second teacher was essential if any real progress was to be made.

"If the work on our living quarters can be completed as I outlined for Mr. Lawrence, we will have an extra room which can be used as a bedroom in case of necessity. This would permit a third person to live in the teachers' house.

"There is question of opening a class in the basement. This, I think, would be as good an arrangement as any we can foresee, at present."

Our records here show that for the March quarter the attendance at this school averaged 40. For the month of April it averaged 39.47. Therefore, we are quite prepared to pay for a second teacher at this school. The big problem will be the provision of a second classroom.

So have already written to you with regard to the expenditure of $495 in making alterations and repairs to the teacher's living quarters. Do you think that the use of the basement as a classroom is a feasible suggestion or would you prefer the use of the council hall, as I discussed with you last winter?

Herbert F. Murray,
Superintendent of Education."
Dear Mr. Lawrence,

I have another teacher for daywork who would be willing to teach even in the basement. She has 12th grade finished—has no certification and some teaching experience. She is trying to get enough money for normal.

However, the basement seems hardly feasible. Reasons against: too little for wood—nothing extra for furniture and supplies and too much expense involved to obtaining enough light or eliminating dampness. This ultimately the living conditions would be unsatisfactory.

The best solution seems to be to let the hall be fixed up for education.
and I could give up my Latin
for two quarters if she could
work with the teachers.
Let me know what you
think so I can tell the girl what
to expect.

E. M. Hey J.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

June 2, 1948.

I am enclosing letter received from Rev. J. A. Mokey, S.J., Parish Priest, of the Spanish River Indian Reserve regarding another teacher for the Spanish River ... C. Indian School, and in which he states that his cabin could be used for living quarters. He also states that he does not think the basement would be suitable as a classroom and thinks the best solution would be to fix up the Indian Hall.

I think myself that the Hall would perhaps make the best temporary quarters for the small children. It would take at least $495.00 to put the Hall in shape for the winter, as at present it is only a shell.

You cannot get anyone to go on this reserve and make a bid on small jobs such as this, so if the Department is interested in putting this extra classroom under way by next fall, I would appreciate it if an accountable advance could be forwarded this office as soon as possible for $350.00 for labour to put this hall in shape for next fall.

Kindly advise me regarding this matter at your convenience so that I can notify Father Mokey regarding the teacher.

P. J. Laurence,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Baillie Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Re: Spanish River R.C. Indian Day School

Further to my recent letter concerning the general building programme in your Superintendency, I would like to make a further suggestion concerning the building of the above school.

As you are aware, we are at the present time renting the Council Hall for use as a second classroom. Mr. Laurence, when on his holidays in Ottawa recently, discussed this situation with me and we agreed that a standard one-room school without basement (Plan No. 838) would be quite satisfactory for this part of the reserve. I would suggest that it be built close to the present building and arrangements be made to purchase additional land for a playground area.

It would seem that we can proceed to advertise for a contractor for the erection of this building without any further delay. If so, the only delay would seem to be concerning the water supply. As there is already an adequate well at the present school, I would not imagine this will present too much difficulty.

Bernard X. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Sagamook Indian Day School.

I have just finished discussing with Mr. Doucet the attached sketch of the proposed site of the new school.

We are agreed that if possible it would be preferable to move the school closer to the fence on the north. If it is at all possible to do this then the school could be turned completely around so that the residence would face East and the wall of windows would face South.

If this is not possible then could the school be oriented to face East or West and move closer to the west fence. It would be preferable to have the wall of windows face East.

SAGAMOOK INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

I wish to acknowledge your letter of April 13th, 1949, file 454-5 (2) regarding the proposed site of the new school.

It would be possible to move the school closer to the fence and turn it completely around so that the residence would face East and the wall of windows face South.

The reason I placed the wall of windows in the new school facing North is because the wall of windows in the existing school face North. By turning the school around as you suggested both classrooms would be looking into each other and I thought that this might distract the pupils' attention.

The wall of windows could be made to face East, but Father Mokey, S.J., the local Parish Priest, and myself discussed the matter and both of us were of the opinion that for appearance sake it would be better to have both schools facing the same direction rather than one at right angles to the other. There is no reason for not having the school face East.

You will note that the North-east corner of the property is marked "low ground". I believe that it would be advisable before building the new school to fill this portion in with gravel so that it could be used as a playground. Two or three hundred yards of gravel would be sufficient to do this.

R. P. G. Laurence,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

people tank seems the only solution.

DATE Nov. 14, 1949
Dear Mr. Neary:

The accompanying requisition looks like a big order, but really only amounts to a few changes which not only I, but any other teacher who succeeds me will appreciate. A copy has gone on to Mr. Lawrence. We hope you concur.

Mr. Neary this has been the most difficult assignment I have ever had, but thanks to being "hard-up" I have had the necessary stick-to-it-iveness to go on, although several times I felt beaten.

Regarding the desks, Mr. Neary, we have had no place for individual material—which makes for much confusion.

Besides my school work I have just completed thirty-five visits to Indian homes. In some cases it was just a social call, in others illness and death. I had one fracture case and one of blood poison to the doctor. The Welfare Dept. should make some provision for transporting patients for treatment. The Indians depend altogether too much on the Missionary for this.

Has there a mistake in my salary rating? According to the bulletin I should receive more.

Hoping for favorable consideration, I am respectfully,

[Signature]

Blackboards

Bulletin board over these on both sides (ten feet or other wall board).

(1) Provision made for heating and lighting.

Kitchen

of a small built-in cabinet with a work-table
(1) a built-in breakfast corner—carpenter makes
table and two benches (one partition all around)

wood is used)?

Bed-room

with shelves between)

Provision made for lighting in house.
Shelves built on both sides with doors
(keep supplies cool).

Closed-in steps were asked for on both
entrances (to avoid accidents in slippery
and wet conditions).

One book-box on children's desks.
The present tin boxes are now so
worn out to be entirely useless for
their purpose intended so we do succeed
in drawing them but we are unable
to burn them back. I suggest that
while the carpenters are here, these be
replaced by wooden boxes. The ones can
be removed and placed on those. I have

Sanitation

We hoped for this but apparently it is
not to be.

Wm. MacPhee

December 12th, 1949.

Miss Sadie Burke,
Girls' Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ontario.

Dear Miss Burke:

We received your letter of October 6th with reference to providing an indoor toilet at the Sagamook Indian Day School.

After considerable correspondence, we find that at the present time it will be impossible to install the type of toilet you suggest as it will be necessary to provide a cesspool, and owing to the winter conditions it is not practical to carry out the work at this time of the year.

I regret that it is not possible to meet your wishes, but we are instructing Superintendent Laurence to let us know as soon as the weather moderates sufficiently in the spring to install a cesspool. We will then arrange to have the installation of the type of toilet required carried out.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
PP/ST
Chief, Education Division

Re: New Sagamook School.

The heating stoves supplied for this school are really coal stoves and not very satisfactory for burning wood. Kindly advise me if it will be in order to obtain about three (3) tons of hard coal for the above mentioned stoves. If this was allowed, it would be possible to keep the classroom fire at night during the cold weather, and the classroom would be warm in the morning. However, before getting the coal, it would be necessary to build a coal shed.

To build a shed, in keeping with the school, I estimate it would cost about $175.00, $95.00 for material and $80.00 for labour.

Four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) was advanced this office for building this school, and there is approximately $550.00 of this amount remaining.

Kindly advise if this money could be used for building a coal shed.

Sir:

I have your letter of 10th instant, enclosing a resolution of the Manitoulin Island Unceded Band in Council, requesting the erection of a day school building on the Rabbit Island section of the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve.

In reply I have to say that the establishment of a day school on the section of the reserve referred to has been under consideration of the Department, and it is hoped to be able to provide, in our Appropriation for the coming fiscal year, the funds required for the erection of a building. However, I am not in a position to state, at the present time, if the amount necessary for the purpose will be approved by Parliament at the coming session. It will likely be about the middle of April next, before we will be definitely aware whether sufficient funds to erect the building will be available.

In the meantime, consideration might be given to the selection of a site, in a locality that would be central to meet the requirements of the Indian children who would attend. The site chosen should be level, dry, permit of good drainage and be approximately one acre in extent. No doubt, the Indians would agree to providing a site, without expense, or at least at little cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rabbit Island - To erect school building with teacher's living quarters - $4,000.

The above amount is provided in the Estimates, 1935-36, for the erection of a new school building, with teacher's living quarters, at the Rabbit Island Settlement, 4 miles from the village of Wikwemikong, on the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve. The building will require to accommodate 34 children. There should be small cloak-rooms for boys and girls. It will be necessary, also, to provide outside toilets, one for boys and one for girls.

Regarding a site, Mr. Agent Lewis has been requested to give the matter consideration and choose a site that will be central to meet the requirements of the Indian children who will attend. He was also instructed to see that the site chosen is level, dry, permits of good drainage and that it be approximately one acre in extent.

Since over five years the Indians were promised a school (grand) at Rabbit Island. As the gentlemen were going two or three times a year from your department to visit the place then chosen for the building, they, the Indians and I, were always under the impression that the Department would fulfill his promise. Ottawa, October 28, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department is considering in the Estimates for 1938-39, provision for a new one-room Day School on the Rabbit Island section of the Manitoulin Unceded Reserve.

In order that we may have full information, I would appreciate an early reply to the following questions:

(1) The approximate number of children for which provision should be made.

(2) Is the site available, or will it be necessary to purchase a site? In either event, you should state the size of the site you consider necessary and the general condition of the land, viz: whether level or sloping. You should also mention the direction in which you consider the building should face.

(3) Will it be necessary to provide living quarters for the teacher, in connection with the School?

(4) Can drinking water be easily obtained on the site recommended by you?

(5) Would you recommend construction by contract or by day labour?

(6) Do you consider a full basement advisable?
With reference to Departmental Letter No.19-16-1 of the 25th of October last, advising me that the Department is considering in the Estimates for 1938-39 provisions for a new one-room Day School on the Rabbit Island section of the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve, and have made request for certain information, I have the honour to report that at the present time there are twenty-eight children in this section. Two years ago there were thirty-nine. On account of there not being a school, members of these families moved out to sections where their children would be able to attend school, but as this is an agricultural section the majority of the families will return to their farms as soon as there is a school in existence. It is my opinion that provision should be made for classroom accommodation for at least thirty-six pupils.

A suitable site for a school building has been obtained, and the Quit Claim Deed filed with the Department, which was acknowledged by Official Letter No.19-16-9 of the 24th of September, 1936. This parcel of land contains one acre, is level and free from stone. If the building is erected on this site it should face the easterly direction.

It will be necessary to provide living quarters for the teacher, in connection with the school, as there is not an Indian home close to the proposed school who could provide suitable accommodation.

Drinking water can be obtained on this site by digging a well to a depth of twelve to fifteen feet.

I consider that a basement under the teacher's living quarters would provide sufficient cellar room to store vegetables and supplies besides there would be ample space to install a distern. I would recommend that the building be heated with wood stoves instead of a furnace.

I would recommend construction by contract, but Indians to be given employment.

A building similar to the Birch Island combined school and teacher's residence in this Agency would be suitable for the Rabbit Island section. A plan of this building is enclosed.

I enc.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sirs-

I am in receipt of your letter of November 2nd, with reference to the proposed school on the Rabbit Island section of the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve.

It is noted that you suggest that a basement be placed under the teacher's living quarters only and that the building be heated with wood stoves. The Department favours a full basement as this permits of a room for manual training purposes in the basement. In the event of a furnace being installed, should a wood furnace be secured?

Please let me have full particulars regarding the best method of shipping materials. Will it be necessary to ship materials by train into Little Current and have them transported from that point to the school. If so, you should advise the distance from Little Current to the site of the proposed school and the cost per day of hiring trucks for transport purposes. Would it be possible to deliver the material by boat and, if so, you should state if it would be feasible to engage a boat at Owen Sound or Midland to transport the material. In this event you should state at what point on the island the material would be landed and the approximate distance of this point from the site of the school.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of Departmental Letter No.196-I of the 2nd instant with further reference to the proposed school on the Rabbit Island section of the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve, and asking for full particulars regarding the best method of shipping materials. I have the honour to report that it all depends on where the material is purchased, as to where it should be shipped. If material is purchased at Sudbury or along the line it would be necessary to ship to Little Current by train, and then truck to Rabbit Island a distance of approx. 40 miles. The heavy trucks for transport are rather expensive as the owners charge at the rate of 15 cents per mile. All material could be procured at Owen Sound and shipped by boat to Manitowaning, which is a distance of fifteen miles from the proposed school site. It would not be necessary to engage a boat at Owen Sound to transport the material, as there are two boats weekly from Owen Sound to Manitowaning and would advise this way of shipping.

In the event of a furnace being installed, it should be a wood furnace.

I might say for the information of the Department, that on examining the old school building at Wikwemikong recently, I find that there is a large quantity of good sound material in this building that could be utilized in the building of the proposed school at Rabbit Island. The old building could be taken down in the spring by Indian labour at a low cost, and the distance to truck the material from Wikwemikong would be only four miles.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

In accordance with the instructions contained in your recent letter I wish to advise that I took charge of the Rabbit Island school on September 19th and I now have matters in such shape, insofar as prospective students and their parents are concerned, that I can start teaching just as soon as the desks are received and installed and supplies are received.

Mr. Lewis advises me that he has the shipping advice covering the desks and they should be here any day now. Supplies which you state in your letter to Mr. Lewis are being shipped from the Stationery Branch in Ottawa have not yet come to hand and I would appreciate it if they could be sent along at an early date.

I would like to point out that no provision has been made for a water supply for this school. Indications are that the attendance will be fairly heavy and water supply is essential. Would you kindly take this matter up in the proper quarters in order that the necessary work may be undertaken and completed as soon as possible. At present I am carrying drinking water from a well at a farm house and which involves a round trip of about one half mile and am getting water for other purposes from a creek near the school. As Mr. Lewis appears to have a great many things to attend to and it may be some time before he has an opportunity to get out here and give the chance to take up the matter of a well with him I thought that the mention of this matter here might speed up the provision of a suitable water supply before the cold weather sets in. From all indications it would appear that a well could be dug and a suitable platform and pump installed at a very reasonable cost.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Teacher.
Ottawa,
October 5, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the teacher of the Rabbit Island Indian Day School in which she points out that no provision has been made for a water supply. She further advises that from inquiries she has made she considers that a well could be dug at a reasonable cost.

I should appreciate hearing from you in regard to this matter immediately. If the teacher's suggestion is feasible the Department would be prepared to favourably consider authorizing the digging of a well before the cold weather sets in provided that it can be done at a reasonable cost and you consider that there is a likelihood of obtaining water.

The school desks were ordered from the Vilas Furniture Company, Comancheville, Que., on September 21. They will be shipped to you at Little Current. If the desks have not yet arrived you should communicate with the freight agent at that point and request him to notify you when the desks arrive in order that you can arrange for immediate acceptance of the shipment and place the desks in the school.

The school supplies will also be forwarded to Little Current addressed to you. These supplies are leaving Ottawa today and as soon as they reach Little Current you should arrange for their delivery to the school.

Yours truly,

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the Manitowaning agency on the 24th-26th Oct.

RABBIT ISLAND SCHOOL, recently built, is a nice modern building and is very much appreciated by the Indians of this section. It has seating capacity for 31, with 22 pupils on the roll. Dear Sir,

I hope this letter reaches you in good condition. I've asked a few times already at our Indian Office in Montour, about the fencing of our school in Rabbit Island. The school is right on my farm. And I was told by the Secretary in Montour Indian Office, that until you give word to them about the school fence, to be put up by your work.

I wouldn't mind if the school was outside the fence. It's the gate that bothers me. The people and the school pupils leave it open, and then the cattle, horses & pigs come into my field. Or would it be better to put rails where the gate is? I had put that gate there myself last fall when the school was done.

I also wish that I could get help for myself in putting up the fence. I hope that you don't overlook this letter, and also hope that you don't misunderstand this letter, and also hope that you don't misunderstand this letter.

I think that really good work is being done at Rabbit Island.

Dear Sir:

Reporting on his visit to the Rabbit Island day school on October 19 Inspector Greening writes:

"Wise Allen was one of the three teachers from the Manitoulin area who took the course in Home Economics at Ottawa this summer. She would like to do as much work as possible in Home Economics. To do so, she will need a large work table. It would also be a great advantage if a sink were placed in the kitchen.

"The door of one of the toilets had been blown off its hinges. The seat covers were gone, and the toilets were dirty."

You might let me know the cost of securing the table recommended by the Inspector.

The minor repairs to which the Inspector refers in the second paragraph of his report should have received immediate attention. Indian agents are expected to see that toilets are kept in a cleanly condition and that small repairs are made at once.

Yours truly,

Mr. C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent,
Manitouaning, Ont.

Sir:

Replying to your letter No.19-16-5 dated December 8th, I wish to report, I can have made a large table 3' x 6' with two large drawers for approximately $14.00 for labour and material complete.

In reply to letter No.19-16-4 dated September 27th, 1939 regarding placing of bars on basement windows of Rabbit Island School, it is possible to procure a galvanized electric weld fabric No.9 gauge 2" x 2" mesh, which would cost about $14.00 for 300 sq.ft., which would be much more preferable to the placing of bars on the windows, as it gives the added protection against damage from baseballs while the children are playing ball in the grounds.

It would require about 100 square feet for Rabbit Island School, and can be put on frames or attached to the present window frames with staples to keep out marauders as well. It would cost very little to attach to the present window frames; but, if we decided to have special frames made to attach it to, the cost would come a little higher, possibly five or six dollars for material and labour making the frames.

However, I would recommend having this material supplied. It appeals to me as an ideal protection against marauders, as well as for the glass.

Yours very truly,

September 5, 1942

Sir:

I wish to report there are a few minor repairs needed at Rabbit Island School, if the funds are available.

There was about $21.00 refunded from Birch Island and Suzwah schools on the advance to pay for labour, and I hope we may be able to keep under the estimate on Kaboni and Wikwemikong as well.

A few loads of earth and gravel are required close to the school to run the water away, as we have had some difficulty with surface water coming in the basement. About $5.00 for labour should cover this.

The entrance platforms and steps should also be painted and the floors oiled in classroom. This work was authorized last year, but was too wet for the outside work by the time the painters got around to it.

The furnace pipes also need some repairs, and the teacher asked to have an approach to the two outside toilets. This could be made of lattice work and painted, which would have a good appearance, but personally I do not see that it will serve any useful purpose, and I am unable at present to give a very accurate estimate, as I presume the funds are not available.

The other work is quite urgent and should not cost over $25.00 for labour. A requisition for the material is enclosed herewith.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Canada.

Ottawa, October 19, 1943.

Mr. C. R. Johnston, Indian Agent, Manitowaning, Ont.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 14th instant, in which you recommend the purchase of a piano, at an approximate cost of $100.00, for the Rabbit Island Indian Day School.

I cannot remember the purchase of a piano or an organ for an Indian day school at any time, anywhere, since I entered the Department, 7 years ago. I have, however, at the time of my visits to a number of Indian day schools, noticed organs and pianos in use. The pianos, in every case I was informed, were purchased with funds usually collected by the teacher from Christmas concerts, special lectures, etc.

In view of the fact that no provision has been made in the estimates of this year for the expenditure of an additional $100.00 at the Rabbit Island School, I have been wondering if it would be possible to interest the local people, particularly the Indians, in the purchase of this instrument. We are naturally anxious to do everything humanly possible to satisfy our teachers, but the funds at our disposal during this critical period are very limited. You might write to us again with respect to this matter.

R. A. Rossy,

MEMORANDUM TO FILE:

RABBIT ISLAND INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

TEACHER

Mrs. Agnes Wakerigig

This teacher has had 10 years' experience and holds a second class certificate. Her discipline is good and the children are progressing fairly well. However, I get the impression that she has been getting by with a minimum of effort for the last few years. I drew to her attention the need for trying new methods and of maintaining the interest of her students. At the present time her teaching is rather mechanical.

TRACK, RACK AND SCHOOL

This is a very good building, approximately 10 years old. The teacher's quarters are very good and attached to the school-room in the usual way. There is one bedroom upstairs and a living room and kitchen down stairs. There is no Hydro or running water and the school is rather isolated. It is the most isolated school on Manitoulin, in fact.

There is a full cement basement with plenty of light. It would be ideal for a manual training instructor. There is a good furnace and the school is warm and comfortable. The classroom is well lighted, with five windows on one side and one on the other.

Ottawa, April 13, 1910.

Sir,

A return has just been received from the Seine River school. In this connection it is noted that the school was closed from March 31, 1909, to January 1, 1910, a period of nine months, when it was apparently re-opened by Mr. Spence.

The Department would like to know by whose authority the school was closed and re-opened, as well as the reason for closing.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

J. P. Wright, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Frances, Ont.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of 13th instant,

No. 259947/1, relative to the Seine River Indian Day School, in reply I beg to state that there are only six families that reside on the reserve near the school, and as they all left the reserve in April last for their spring hunt, and took their families with them, the teacher Peter Spence came home, and as none of these Indians returned to their homes, to remain any length of time until late in the fall, the teacher did not reopen the school until January last.

Owing to their nomadic mode of living, it is difficult to get any regular attendance in these day schools, and it was by my authority that the teacher reopened the school in January last, at the request of the Indians.

Mr. Spence, who is a treaty Indian, and belongs to the Little Forks band, has done good work in this school, although he has been badly handicapped by losing one or two quarters during each year he has been teaching there. I have at different times warned these Indians that the Department would probably close their school, if they did not keep up a better attendance.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

December 10, 1936.

The Chief and members of the Seine River Reserve, No. 23A, etc., as it is sometimes known, Wild Potato Lake Reserve, as also the local Indian Agent, have requested for several years the establishment of a day school for the benefit of the Indian children of school age on the reserve. No educational facilities are available for these children. A day school building, with classroom accommodation for forty (40) children, has recently been erected and will be furnished in time for the school to open as from January first, 1937. The services of a teacher have been engaged, with salary at the rate of $80.00 per teaching month, and he will begin duties on the date mentioned above.

Funds to erect the building were provided in the Special Building Programme, Vote No. 31B, and funds to pay salary of teacher and supply desks and other equipment are provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year.
